newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Goodman says first half sales mixed.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Goodman says first half sales mixed.

text.p: Australia and New Zealand food group Goodman Fielder Ltd said on Friday its sales performance was patchy in the first half of the 1996/97 year to June 30, with the rise in net profit due to better financial management.

"Sales performance was mixed with some businesses increasing sales and others offsetting sluggish demand with improved margin management," the company said, also citing a flat profit result before tax and interest of A$121.5 million.
"Despite these factors, net profit increased as a result of improved cash management and lower debt and interest payments, and lower abnormals," it said.
Sales in the latest period fell by one percent to A$2.06 billion, while net profit after abnormals rose to A$55.8 million from A$45.9 million.

The company said key factors in the first half included high global wheat costs which added A$24 million to input costs, costs reductions in all divisions, higher profits for the Meadow Lea margarine unit, a profit rebound for the Steggles chicken unit, and strong performances by operations in Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific.

Sales by Milling and Baking, the company's largest division, rose 1.4 percent to A$471.4 million while earnings before interest and tax (EBIT) fell 28.1 percent to A$30.4 million due to higher wheat prices.

Steggles achieved a rise in EBIT to A$9.8 million from A$3.2 million a year ago and sales rose by 1.5 percent to A$252 million. "A severe industry wide stock shortage fuelled price rises and Steggles benefited from changes in the sales mix from frozen to fresh chicken with higher margins."
The Edible Oils and Foodservice unit increased EBIT by 22.6 percent to A$27.1 million but sales fell 2.5 percent to A$279.5 million.
The Cereals and Snacks unit increased EBIT by 30.1 percent to A$21.6 million and sales fell 1.5 percent to A$238.4 million.
EBIT by the Ingredients division was flat at A$16.4 million from A$16.3 million a year ago and sales fell 1.7 percent to A$161.5 million.
The International division, consisting of South Pacific and Asian operations, increased EBIT to A$8.4 million from A$5.1 million on a 3.0 percent sales rise to A$137.7 million.
